core_courses.objective: The course is designed to help learners develop a broad understanding of the fundamental and advanced concepts of cell biology from a human-centred perspective. A major emphasis of the course will be on the recent advances in cell biology and its importance to human health and disease.
core_courses.contents: Introduction to cell biology, Biogenesis and functions of plasma membrane, Cytoskeletal elements, Cell Division: Mitosis and Meiosis, Mitochondrial biogenesis and function, Protein import, Biosynthesis of ER and Golgi, Trans-Golgi Network, Vesicular trafficking, Lysosome biogenesis and pathophysiology, Nucleus- structure and biogenesis of nuclear envelope, Nuclear import and export, Cell cycle and Cell death, Regulation of signalling pathways, Physiological methods to characterize and understand cellular processes.
textbooks: 1. Molecular Biology of Cell, Bruce Alberts (2014) 6th edition. Garland Science
2. Cell Biology, Pollard TD, Earnshaw WC, Schwartz JL. (2016) 3rd Edition Elsevier Publishing Co.

core_courses.objective: This course aims to provide fundamental concepts of biochemistry, starting from simple building blocks to complex metabolism.
core_courses.contents: Basic principles: Biomolecules, Stereoisomers and life, thermodynamics of biochemical reactions; Structural biochemistry: Protein Structure, Protein Folding, Learning Pymol, Enzyme Catalysis, Enzyme Kinetics, Lipid structure and membrane assembly, Carbohydrate structure; Bioenergetics: Glycolysis, Glycolysis of red blood cells and liver, Bacterial Energetics, The citric acid cycle, Electron transport, ATP synthesis, Regulation of blood sugar; Tissue-specific metabolism: Liver metabolism, Muscle metabolism, Brain Metabolism; Synthesis and degradation of Biomolecules: Nucleic acid metabolism, Carbohydrate metabolism, Fatty acid metabolism, Protein metabolism. Buffer preparation, pH meter calibration and pH adjustment. Estimation of proteins lowry/bradford. Estimation of DNA, RNA, protein by spectrophotometer
textbooks: 1. Lehninger Principles of Biochemistry (WH Freeman, 7th Edition, 2017) by David L. Nelson and Michael M. Cox
2. Voet′s Principles of Biochemistry (John Wiley & Sons, 5th Edition, 2018) by Donald Voet, Judith G. Voet, Charlotte W. Pratt

core_courses.objective: The objective of this course is to provide fundamental concepts of the advances in the biotechnology field including methodologies, applications and the ethical issues involved.
core_courses.contents: Introduction to biomolecular organization. Recombinant DNA technology methodologies and applications: Plasmid DNA isolation, Plasmid transformation, Restriction digestion & DNA gel electrophoresis, and Polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Genetic methodologies in application of bacterial and yeast cells in biotechnology. Genetically modified plants and their applications in the production of medically important biomolecules. Biotechnology-based diagnostic and therapeutic strategies for human diseases. Ethical issues in the usage of genetically modified plant and animal systems.
textbooks: 1. Molecular Biotechnology by Bernard R. Glick, and Jack J. Pasternak, 5th Edition, 2017.
2. Guide to Yeast Genetics and Molecular Biology. Christine Guthrie, Gerald R. Fink. Academic Press, 2002.

core_courses.objective: The learning outcome of this course is an overview of vertebrate immune system and detailed knowledge of the essential components of the immune system
core_courses.contents: Overview of Immunology; Innate and adaptive immunity; Antigen and antibody: Structure and function; Antigen-antibody interactions as tools for research; Generation of antibody diversity: Immunoglobulin genes; Presentation of antigen by major histocompatibility complex molecules, cytokines; complement; Effector mechanisms; T-cell development; B-cell development; AIDS and the immune system; Vaccines. Special topics on advances in immunology. Rocket Immunoelectrophoresis Sandwich ELISA Ouchterlony Double Diffusion for Antigen-Antibody patterns or Western blot.
textbooks: 1. Goldsby, Kindt, and Osborne. Kuby Immunology 6th ed. Freeman, 2007.
2. Roitt's Essential Immunology. 12th Edition.Peter J. Delves,Seamus J. Martin, Dennis R. Burton,Ivan M. Roitt
references: 3. David Male, Jonathan Brostoff, David Roth, Ivan Roitt, Immunology; Mosby Publisher, 7th ed. 2006

core_courses.objective: The objective of this course is to partially bridge the gap between academia and industry. The course is taught by the leaders of the Research and Development of Biotech industry. In this course students learn latest trends in industrial biotech research directly from the scientists.
core_courses.contents: Industry lectures from biotech R&D leaders covering latest trends in industrial biotechnology research.

departmental_electives_sem1.objective: Outline of biomacromolecular structures and algorithms for biomolecular structure prediction.
departmental_electives_sem1.contents: Biomolecular Structure & Dynamics, stereochemistry, nucleic acid structures, sequence alignment, phylogenetics, protein structure prediction.
textbooks: Martin Egli, Wolfram Saenger, Principles of Nucleic Acid Structure, Springer, 1983

departmental_electives_sem1.contents: Genetic manipulation, cloning, sequencing, expression systems, genetic libraries, DNA microarrays, GMO generation and analysis.

departmental_electives_sem1.objective: Insights into molecular mechanisms of protein misfolding linked to neurodegeneration.
departmental_electives_sem1.contents: Protein folding/misfolding, amyloidogenicity, Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Huntington's, prion diseases, chaperones, therapeutics.

departmental_electives_sem1.objective: Overview of eukaryotic cells, organelles, and current research techniques.
departmental_electives_sem1.contents: Cell structure, microscopy, membrane transport, signaling, cytoskeleton, mammalian cell culture, transfection techniques.
textbooks: Molecular Cell Biology, Lodish et al., 6th Ed., W.H. Freeman, 2008
Current Protocols in Cell Biology, John Wiley & Sons, 2012
references: Molecular Biology of The Cell, Alberts et al., 5th Ed., Garland Science, 2010

departmental_electives_sem1.objective: Detailed knowledge of membrane receptors and their biomedical applications.
departmental_electives_sem1.contents: Receptor classification, pharmacodynamics, ion channels, assay technologies, cardiovascular pharmacology.

departmental_electives_sem1.objective: Understanding circadian clocks and their physiological and clinical significance.
departmental_electives_sem1.contents: Biological oscillators, circadian clocks, molecular mechanisms, physiological functions, circadian disorders, chrononutrition.

departmental_electives_sem1.objective: Understanding RNA biology, gene regulation, and RNA-based therapeutics.
departmental_electives_sem1.contents: RNA types and structure, processing, RNA interference, RNA therapeutics, CRISPR-Cas RNA targeting, RNA in diseases.

RNA Biology, Robert J. Schneider, Wiley, 2017

departmental_electives_sem1.objective: How the eukaryotic genome is organized in the cell nucleus during interphase and packaged into chromosomes during mitosis, and how its packaging affects gene regulation? This course familiarizes students with this research area, its significance in human diseases, and advanced technologies to study 3D genome organization.
course_contents: Eukaryotic genome organization in cell nucleus and chromosomes during cell division
Spatial genome organization and dynamics
Chromosome territories, nuclear architecture and gene regulation
Chromosome dynamics during mitosis and meiosis
Mitotic bookmarking/epigenetic transcription memory
Chromatin remodeling and transcription
3D genome organization (TADs) and transcription regulation
The 4D Nucleome project
Role of phase separation and loop extrusion in 3D genome organization
Human diseases associated with defects in genome organization
Role of 3D genome organization in development and differentiation

Techniques to study chromosome dynamics and gene regulation (3C, immunofluorescence, chromatin spread, FISH, ChIP, live cell imaging, FRAP, RT-qPCR, smFISH, live transcript analysis, single-molecule imaging)
text_books: Nuclear Organization and Function by Terri Grodzicker, David Spector, and David Stewart; Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press; ISBN: 1936113082
The Nucleus by Tom Mistelli and David Spector; Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press; ISBN: 0879698942
Genome Organization and Function in the cell nucleus by Karsten Rippe; Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH; ISBN: 9783527639991
research_articles: Dekker, J., Belmont, A., Guttman, M. et al. The 4D nucleome project. Nature 549, 219–226 (2017)
Zheng, H., Xie, W. The role of 3D genome organization in development and cell differentiation. Nat Rev Mol Cell Biol 20, 535–550 (2019)
Rowley, M. J., & Corces, V. G. Organizational principles of 3D genome architecture. Nature reviews. Genetics, 19(12), 789–800 (2018)

departmental_electives_sem1.objective: Emphasis on techniques used to determine and analyze macromolecular organization and interactions. Uses case studies to understand biological processes from structure information.
course_contents: Quantification and characterization of interactions involving proteins and ligands
Characterization of macromolecular assembly using biophysical techniques
Principles of protein and nucleic acid structures
Covalent, non-covalent, and van der Waals interactions in structure and folding
Use of Ramachandran plots and other tools for structure validation
Graphic tools to visualize and analyze atomic structures
Bioinformatics tools for analyzing motifs and folds
Protein and nucleic acid folding problems
Case studies to understand biological phenomena with structures
text_books: Protein-Ligand Interactions: hydrodynamics and calorimetry (A Practical Approach) by S. E. Harding and B. Z. Chowdhry; Oxford University Press; 2001
Introduction to Protein Structure by C. Branden and J. Tooze; 2nd edition; Garland Science; 1999
Biophysical Chemistry: Part II: Techniques for the Study of Biological Structure and Function by Charles R. Cantor and Paul R. Schimmel
reference_books: Biophysics: An Introduction by R. Glaser; Springer; 2010, 2012
Textbook of Structural Biology by A. Liljas et al.; World Scientific Publishing; 2009

departmental_electives_sem1.course_name: Molecular mechanisms of aging and age-related disorders
departmental_electives_sem1.objective: Provide basic understanding of molecular mechanisms underlying aging and how cellular processes change during aging and age-related diseases. Covers therapeutic approaches to delay or reverse aging.
course_contents: Review of cellular processes such as transcription, translation, posttranslational modifications, signaling pathways
Mechanisms of aging and regeneration
Model systems to study aging
Changes in cellular processes with aging
Genetic basis of aging and age-related disorders (obesity, diabetes, neuromuscular disease, cardiovascular disease, cancers)
Therapeutic approaches to delay or reverse aging
text_books: Molecular Biology of Cell by Bruce Alberts; 6th edition; Garland Science; 2014
Biology of Aging by R.B. McDonald; 2nd edition; Taylor & Francis; 2019
reference_material: Hallmarks of aging: An expanding universe by Carlos López-Otín et al.; Cell; 2023; doi:10.1016/j.cell.2022.11.001

departmental_electives_sem2.objective: The course aims at providing required knowledge of advances in protein research for industrial and medical applications to post graduate students.
departmental_electives_sem2.contents: Overview of Protein structure and function. Recombinant protein expression systems: E.coli, Pichia, Insect-cells, cell-free protein expression systems. Protein purification techniques: Ion-exchange chromatography; Gel-filtration; Affinity chromatography; FPLC; HPLC. Small and large scale purification; Protein characterization: Two-dimensional Gel electrophoresis; Mass spectrometry; Proteomics; Fluorescence Spectrometry; Circular Dichroism, Isothermal Titration Calorimetry. Protein folding-misfolding; Inclusion bodies; Mutant design and site-directed mutagenesis; Therapeutic proteins.
textbooks: Introduction to Protein Structure; Carl Branden & John Tooze, 2nd edition, Garland Publishing, 1999
Molecular Biotechnology, Bernard R. Glick, Jack J. Pasternak, 4th Edn, 2010
The Protein Protocol Handbook; John M Walker, Humana Press, 2009
references: Introducing Proteomics; Josip Lovric, Wiley Press, 2011
Therapeutic Proteins: Methods and Protocols (Methods in Molecular Biology), C. Mark Smales, David C. James, Humana Press, 2005
Exploring Proteins; Nick Price & Jacqueline Narin, Oxford University Press, 2009

departmental_electives_sem2.objective: The course provides detailed view of nature engineering a multicomponent system. Students will understand the processes carried out by the molecular machines, structural details of components, coordination of functions, and characterization techniques.
departmental_electives_sem2.contents: Introduction: DNA-protein interactions; DNA polymerase as a multifunctional molecular machine; Endonuclease mechanisms; DNA repair; Recombination (homologous and non-homologous); Transposition (jumping genes); Topoisomerase; Telomerase; Epigenetic modifications.
references: Lewin's Genes X, Jocelyn E. Krebs, Elliott S. Goldstein, Stephen T. Kilpatrick, Oxford University Press, 2011
Molecular Biology of the Cell, 5th Edition, Bruce Alberts et al., Garland Science, 2008

departmental_electives_sem2.objective: To provide fundamental concepts in NMR and applications in understanding biomolecular structure and dynamics.
departmental_electives_sem2.contents: Properties of electromagnetic radiation; Magnetic properties of nuclei; Nucleus in a magnetic field; Spin populations; NMR phenomenon; Classical vector model; Chemical shift; J coupling; FID; One-pulse experiment; Relaxation; Inversion-recovery; Spin-echo; Chemical exchange; Instrumentation; NOE; 2D and 3D NMR experiments; Sequential assignment strategies.
textbooks: Understanding NMR Spectroscopy, James Keeler, Wiley, 2011
Fundamentals of Protein NMR Spectroscopy, Gordon S. Rule, T. Kevin Hitchens, Springer, 2006
Biomolecular NMR Spectroscopy, Jeremy N. S. Evans, Oxford, 1995
references: NMR of Proteins and Nucleic Acids, Kurt Wüthrich, Wiley-Interscience, 1986
Modern NMR Spectroscopy: A Guide for Chemists, 2nd edition, Jeremy K. M. Sanders, Brian K. Hunter, Oxford University Press, 1993 (reprinted 2009)

departmental_electives_sem2.objective: This course is designed to give insights on macromolecules crystallization and resolving their structure by X-ray crystallography.
departmental_electives_sem2.contents: Macromolecules crystallization: rational approaches and methods; Protein-protein and protein-nucleic acid crystallization; Crystal symmetry and systems; X-ray diffraction; Structure factors; Phase problem; Electron density equation; Phasing methods; Model building and refinement; Ramachandran plots and structure validation; Graphics tools for visualization; Case studies.
textbooks: Protein Crystallography, T. L. Blundell, L. N. Johnson, Academic Press, 1976
Outline of Crystallography for Biologists, D. Blow, Oxford University Press, 2002
references: Biomolecular Crystallography: Principles, Practice, and Application to Structural Biology, B. Rupp, Garland Science, 2009

departmental_electives_sem2.objective: To provide detailed understanding of the nature, distribution, and activities of microbes and their impact on health, especially as agents of clinical infectious diseases.
departmental_electives_sem2.contents: Introduction to Medical Microbiology; Microscopy of microorganisms; Morphology and nature; Classification and identification; Bacterial growth and metabolism; Sterilization and disinfection; Antimicrobial agents; Human microbiome; Pathogenicity; Adaptive immunity; Host-microbe interactions; Diseases caused by bacteria, viruses, prions, fungi, protists; Diseases of skin, eyes, nervous, cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, urinary, reproductive systems; COVID-19; Infection control and epidemiology; Systems level approaches to study infections.
references: Jacquelyn G. Black and Laura J. Black, Microbiology Principles and Explorations, Wiley, 10th Edition, 2018
Joanne Willey, Kathleen Sandman and Dorothy Wood, Prescott's Microbiology, McGraw Hill, 11th Edition, 2020

departmental_electives_sem2.objective: This course is designed to provide knowledge about the interdisciplinary approach to address biological problems.
departmental_electives_sem2.contents: Linux commands: ls, vim, emacs, grep, sed, awk etc.; shell scripting: if condition, while loop etc. and their application in editing, organizing and transferring Protein Databank (PDB) files towards modeling and analyses of biomacromolecular structures. Python scripting for genomic/proteomic sequence analysis.

A Practical Guide to Linux, Commands, Editors and Shell Programming by Mark G Sobell, 2014, Pearson
Learning Python (5th Edition) by Mark Lutz, O'Reilly Media, Inc.

departmental_electives_sem2.objective: Deals with the principles of biotechnology applied to the development of drugs.
departmental_electives_sem2.contents: Introduction and history of biologics and biopharmaceuticals; Macromolecular structure relevance to biologics/biosimilars; Stereoisomers and drugs; Biotechnology in rational biodrug design; Role of Biotechnology in vaccine design: Virus-like particles and protein nanocages; Synthesis and downstream processing of bioformulations; Determining product shelf life, stability, toxicity, immunogenicity and product analysis; Pharmacogenetics and chemical genetics in drug discovery; Effect of protein post-translational modifications on protein formulations and production methods.
textbooks: Pharmaceutical Biotechnology: Concepts and Applications, Gary Walsh, Wiley, 2007
Biopharmaceuticals Biochemistry and Biotechnology, 2nd Edition, Gary Walsh, Wiley, 2003

departmental_electives_sem2.objective: Knowledge about use of animal models in medical research. Includes a hands-on module.
departmental_electives_sem2.contents: Various animals as models and their advantages/disadvantages; Animal research in medicine: modeling heart damage, autoimmune diseases, tuberculosis, Parkinson’s; Upcoming vertebrate animal model: zebrafish; Practical session using zebrafish.
textbooks: Animal Models in Cardiovascular Research, David Gross, Springer, 2009
The Laboratory Zebrafish, Claudia Harper and Christian Lawrence, CRC Press, 2010

departmental_electives_sem2.course_name: Essential Fatty acids-Biochemistry, physiology and Clinical significance
departmental_electives_sem2.objective: To make students aware about the role of bioactive lipids in energy homeostasis, cell proliferation, metabolism, inflammatory homeostasis, and process regulation, focusing on Essential Fatty Acids (EFAs).
departmental_electives_sem2.contents: EFAs and their metabolism; Metabolites formed from EFAs and their role in inflammation; Cytokines and eicosanoids relationship; EFAs and free radicals and nitric oxide; EFAs and eicosanoids in chronic inflammation and cancer; Immune checkpoint inhibitors and EFAs; Tumoricidal action of EFAs; EFAs and autoimmune diseases; EFAs and health and disease.

departmental_electives_sem2.course_name: Critical analysis and presentation of biological literatures
departmental_electives_sem2.objective: Enhance critical thinking and communication skills focusing on design, organisation, and oral presentation of scientific literatures.
course_contents: Survey published journal articles
Critically analyze and interpret results of biological experiments
Present data effectively and visually
Communicate science to expert and layman audiences
Explain difficult experimental procedures and complex results
Suggest better experimental approaches
Principles governing design and delivery of seminars on biotechnology and bioinformatics
Identify deficiencies in presentation design and organisation
Foster culture of constructive criticism and feedback

departmental_electives_sem2.additional_info: Curated recent and landmark articles from high-impact journals in Molecular Biology, Biotechnology, and Bioinformatics.

departmental_electives_sem2.course_name: Stem cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine
departmental_electives_sem2.objective: Provide a solid foundation in stem cell biology and related human diseases, covering current and future therapies.

Biochemistry of pluripotency
Stem cell epigenetics
Embryonic and adult stem cells
Tumor stem cells

departmental_electives_sem2.objective: Provide molecular level understanding of cancer.
course_contents: Etiology of cancer
Oncogenes
Signaling pathways in cancer
Tumor suppressor genes
Cell cycle control and cancer
DNA damage and cell cycle checkpoints
Immune system and cancer
Multistep process of carcinogenesis
